summary: The Bride (Uma Thurman) picks up where she left off in volume one with her quest to finish the hit list she has composed of all of the people who have wronged her, including ex-boyfriend Bill (David Carradine), who tried to have her killed four years ago during her wedding to another man. Leaving several dead in her wake, she eventually tracks down Bill in Mexico. Using skills she has learned during her assassin career, she attempts to finish what she set out to do in the first place.

reviews.content: Volume 1 is slightly better
A solid favorite. Kong Fu -gritty Western Action. All that with Uma! There is nothing else to say.

this film had every potential to match up to the heights of the first film. and in some ways, this sequel does go leaps and bounds ahead of the first film, but just when the film is about to cross that line of being better than the first one, it gets drawn back by that self-indulgent storytelling that happens in the last act of the film.

not going to lie, the film does actually have a pretty satisfying conclusion to the story which tarantino introduced us to in the first film. there are some new characters, some amazing fight scenes, great music and ofcourse, the elephant in the room, Bill (finally making an appearance after almost zero screen-time in the first film). but, where this film falters is, in making that personal connection with me which the first one so masterfully did.

the film shocks you in the first act itself when the bride has a fight (more of a beatdown, really) with Bill's brother Budd. I did not expect things to go down the way they did, I was genuinely in awe and grabbing my head trying to figure out what she'll do next. after that massive shock, the film transitions to something weirdly placed but totally important scenes for the whole film really. after that, the film peaks in it's second act when the bride finally has a showdown with elle driver and that was fight scene which left me with goosebumps whose climax was already foreshadowed in the first film (genius tarantino). the third act is where things get way too self-indulgent and things start to seem that they're happening just for the sake of happening and isn't natural (which was the case up until now). this really bogged down the final taste I have for the film a lot and was not expecting to see such an end to what seemed like a battle of the gods.

now, by no means is this film bad. some people may like the ending and that's completely fine. the reason I personally don't have a liking towards it (I don't hate it tho) is because it was just too simple and I was expecting something more creative from a director like tarantino. you can still enjoy the film if you're not thinking too much and if you're not an over-analyzer like me. so, I'd still recommend this to you.

Surprisingly the most emotionally resonant of Tarantino's filmography, the second part of the Kill Bill Duology drops a lot of the over-the-top gore and stylish action prevalent in the first part in order to create a more meditative and touching story that benefits a lot from Uma Thurman's incredible performance and it's numerous references to classic Samurai-Westerns.
A movie that improves on its predecessor, volume 2 has just as much action as it does humor, and sort of the same story but with a good ending.

Not as good as the first one. The violence is gone but also the emotion, which for me is the best thing of the first movie. Its still a great movie. Its just that compared to the first one, everything somehow feels downgraded which is strange for a sequel as the usual thing is just to make it bigger and louder but that makes it unique. You can't watch the first one without the second and vice versa although the two movies share only the characters and the story.

Kill Bill finishes off The Bride's vengeance with a slow burn drama.

Director Quentin Tarantino's neo-Western, martial arts, revenge thriller Kill Bill: Vol. 2 (2004) is something else. Tarantino combines his love of old 70's martial arts pictures and 60's Spaghetti Westerns into a contemplative drama and fierce action revenge thriller. Tarantino's deliberately slow burn pace lets us get to know each character before they die, so that the drama hits harder. I found his crazy style always helps his films feel unique despite how many homages he makes to his favorite classics. Tarantino's writing delivers heartfelt drama and quirky humor with a biting edge. I loved that The Bride gets a happy ending and her daughter back with a touching finale.

Editor Sally Menke's sharp cuts keeps the action moving and then calms down for fewer cuts within conversations for gripping drama. Cinematographer Robert Richardson shoots Kill Bill: Vol. 2 with a sleek framing of close-ups on Uma Thurman or her katana. I like the hectic panning during a swordfight compared to his lovely long held medium shots for the talking. Kill Bill is simply magnificently shot.

Uma Thurman is fierce with her determined face and furious eyes as The Bride. Her martial arts, swordplay, and crawling through dirt are impressive. I found Thurman's dramatic speeches about why she left Bill to be particularly compelling. Uma Thurman was born to play The Bride. David Carradine's charisma chams you as the vile villain Bill. His toxic desire to own The Bride is loathsome. Carradine looked like he had a blast delivering long monologue after monologue as Bill. His final moments are beautifully acted.

Michael Madsen is excellent as the sleazy redneck assassin, now a strip club bouncer, named Budd. Madsen feels guilty and selfish as Budd with a fun smirking villain for Kill Bill: Vol. 2. Daryl Hannah sizzles as the sadistic Elle Driver. Her hateful glares and fearsome fighting with Uma Thurman's Bride are iconic. She feels like an Old Hollywood femme fatale.

Gordon Liu is amazing and hilarious as a kung fu grandmaster Pai Mei. His hysterical hermit is full of vigor and disdain. I loved seeing Liu's precise movements and fun make-up that dresses him up to look like Lo Lieh. Michael Parks' sexist pimp Esteban Viahio is fascinating with his surly line delivery. Samuel L. Jackson has a cool cameo as The Bride's wedding organist Rufus. Larry Bishop is very funny as Budd's strip club owner boss Larry Gomez. Sid Haig also cameos as the bartender! Perla Haney-Jardine is very cute and sweet as The Bride's daughter B.B. Helen Kim's cameo as the assassin Karen Kim is pretty funny.

Composers Robert Rodriguez and RZA do a great job building suspense and an epic feel for Kill Bill: Vol. 2's grand atmosphere. Costume designers Catherine Marie Thomas, Kumiko Ogawa, Kanani Wolf, and Daniel Grant North nail cool jackets and jeans for Uma Thurman and a stylish suit for Daryl Hannah. They give Bill an old Western villain aesthetic too. Make-up artists Heba Thorisdottir and Tysuela Hill-Scott do such fine work to Gordon Liu's Pai Mei.

In all, Kill Bill: Vol. 2 is a riveting 136 minutes of action and drama.

Kill Bill Vol. 2 has a lot of great things to offer, the performances, the action sequences and most of the dialog is pretty great, however i did really feel, that Kill Bill could be one longer movie. Kill Bill Vol. 1 did a lot of the setup for the movie already and Kill Bill Vol. 2 was mostly the same. The fight in the caravan was fantastic, the Japanse master is solid and the ending is pretty great, as in almost all Tarentino movies, however i would have liked a fight between the bride and Bill at the end, now it was mostly dialog. Overall the 2 movies combined are solid work, however dont reach the height it could have reached.
Same as the first one. Good action but nothing amazing

Suffering from a much weaker pacing and a whole lot of plot exposition, Kill Bill: Vol 2 is not nearly as effective, moving or investing as the first one but its performances keep it alive and the last 30 minutes delivers a well-rounded payoff.

In "Vol. 2," Elle and Budd give brilliant performances that captivate the audience. Pai Mei has been killed, Budd has been bitten by a poisonous snake, and Elle is in a frenzy after her eyeballs are gouged out by her mentor and Beatrix. It is the most spectacular scene. It is not as messy as the previous film, but it is a cohesive, high-quality revenge drama. The process of Beatrix Kiddo's reemergence after her burial is truly hilarious, although it gets a little boring from the scene where she meets Bill. It's hard to argue with "Vol. 1," but "Vol. 2" is my personal favorite.

Kill Bill Volume 1 was the first Tarantino movie I had seen at the movie theater. I loved it. So of course I was going to see Volume 2. I don't know why some people like one Volume over the other. It's actually 1 whole movie and the entire movie is amazing.
A bit warmer, deeper and less violent than Vol I, making this a slightly better movie than its predecessor.

idk its just a great revenge movie thats it.

OH YEAH AND ITS BRUTAL AF.
18 years latter and I´m still waiting vernita´s daughter revenge.
Much less fun this time around. still has great moments though. Don't go in expecting it to be as great as the first one but still worth watching if you want more.

While still delivering the same brilliant action from Vol. 1, this the more deliberate and mature half of this epic saga. Tarantino just continues to prove himself as a natural born filmmaker. Perfect from beginning to end

It manages to be technically on par with the first film in almost everything, but I could not put up with some too verbose scenes and the nonsense of the plot, which in some places seems too much even in such a film!
A sequel with a sensational conclusion! Beatrix has her special moment and she made good use of it. Tarantino successfully completes.

Even better than the first. I have absolutely no critique. I'm obsessed with Tarantino's directing style. It's so creative and not seen before. Thurman's acting was top notch as well as David Carradine. Praying for a 3rd movie. I loved how the 2nd was a story along with action/violence. So obsessed. I have nothing more to say.
Of course this movie is just as great as volume 1, but the fight scenes just aren't as drawn out and interesting.
Can't go wrong with a Tarantino action movie, loads of fun with a brilliant revenge story

Kill Bill clearly works better as one complete film but when separating them I rate volume two just slightly lower. While still an excellent film on it's own, as well as a totally satisfying conclusion, volume two does lose some of the energy that made volume one an all time favorite of mine.

Samuel L. Jackson Binge: When looking over Jackson's filmography at the beginning of the month I was surprised to see credits in multiple films that I never remembered seeing him in, with this being the most shocking. I was wracking my brain trying to recall his role and was worried I was really losing my memory, being that I've seen this multiple times and consider it a favorite. I was relieved, yet still a bit surprised, to notice for the the first time that was Jackson as Rufus the church piano player, who apparently plays a real good Love Me Tender.

The movie has a lot of creative action which helps to make it unique in the revenge story genre. David Carradine also really elevates the movie as Bill, there is a lot of buildup to the movie's climax and it's simply perfect.

Whilst not as good as the first movie, I think that it's still pretty good. It starts strong but becomes tonally confused by the final quarter of the film. Still has that amazing soundtrack and great acting of course!
still pretty good, but the ending was disappointing
It's not innovative like the first one, but it doesn't lose its essence, and it's fun.

A little bit longer than it should be (but that is not a big problem), this sequel does everything that a relevant sequel should and it is so hard to do at all. Tarantino started to cement here his name a bona-find director and screenplayer (producer too). An auteur different from every single one we see in Hollywood.
A much slower pace than part one and sometimes a bit baggy, but still a thrilling love letter to martia art cinema and spaghetti westerns.

It trades in it's frenetic style for slower and more calculated action with verbal punches instead of limbs flying everywhere. It's more sophisticated than the first, but it's no less pulpy. It delivers soo many classic lines and moments that this is up there with the best of Tarantino.
Part two takes a more serious tone. Fewer laughs, more tension. A fantastic conclusion to one of the purest forms of truly original cinema we may see in our lifetimes.

I will say there is a large debate in the fan community whether the Kill Bill films should be ranked together as one film (as Tarantino states they should be), or whether they are two separate entities of a franchise as well which one is the better of the two. Upon first watching the films I was a bit disappointed Volume 2 did not have the same amount of camp violence as the first, as this film feels to be more a Spaghetti Western revenge film rather than a Samurai thriller. However, upon the re-watching the film multiple times it is quite obvious through the dialogue, storytelling and excellent cinematography that this is the superior film and is a contender for the top spot of Tarantino's filmography.

The first one was definitely better but that doesn't mean that it's necessarily good. Both movies just feel way too much like the director is convinced he is a genius of cinema and this is his opus magnum we all have to love now.

The first half is really nice. We have this wedding going on at the beginning and we see the incident. We follow the story, step by step, I was interested, because the first volume ended very well and I was excited about what will happen. But then... the second half begins. We have a fight in a trailer and I was mesmerized by it. Tarantino not only has perfect screenwriting skills, but he also can shot an action scene that well. And then, the final confrontation comes and I was at the edge of my seat for the entire time. This ladies and gens is cinema. Pure, gold cinema. I started clapping. I adore Tarantino and his KILL BILL is what I want from cinema.
While not as good as the first, "Kill Bill Vol. 2" is still a great film.
Quentin Tarantino's Masterpiece theatre, I don't enjoy his work, but this was fantastic.
Although it's slower and with more talking than volume 1 it's still a blast from beginning to end.

People tend to prefer Volume 2 over Volume 1 but for me it's the other way around. Volume 2 is slower and longer, but still a fantastic film nonetheless, and the two films complement each other in the best ways possible. This too is one of QT's best flicks.

Hardly a sequel. Really a continuation.   All the great elements of the first half and more.  The flashbacks here are classic.   The sad part about this one is that there isn't a subsequent film.   Uma Thurman and the entire cast are magnificent.   Carradine really shines as he is more prominent in this installment.

In the follow up to Kill Bill Volume 1, Tarantino decides to embark on a more emotional story. In volume 2 we get to learn more about the back story of Beatrix Kiddo and her former lover, Bill, as well as the remaining members of The Deadly Viper Assassination Squad. This continuation is much less reliant on action, but rather the trials and tribulations Beatrix has faced, and her motivations. She continues the bloodbath she started in Volume 1, leading to the satisfying and surprising confrontation with Bill. However, I can't help but fell that Volume 2 was more of an afterthought. It is used to fill in more of the emotional and motivational gaps from Volume 1, probably because the films were originally supposed to be one whole film. But regardless, a fantastic film and a more personal continuation of the Bride's story.

I'd give it a 94%. Loved this film. It picks up in a great spot and fills in a lot of the holes of the story which makes the story of this film much more engaging. The first one felt just like a vengeance tour while this film had more story. The gaps in the story are very intriguing and you still get good fight scenes. 

Bill and Beatrix love each other. Beatrix finds out she's pregnant. She doesn't want Bill to know because he'd claim her as his own but Beatrix didn't want her to grow up in that sort of life. So when she's supposed to be on a mission she never returns. While Bill is tracking down her killers she finds her alive, pregnant, and getting married. He gets pissed off and he and his assassins kill her. When Beatrix confronts him about it later he says he overreacted. Great ending with the way Beatrix kills Bill and ends up with her daughter
While not my favorite Tarantino film, the ninja action and unforgettable fight scenes accompanied by his unique style of directing with a new take makes the viewer stunned and satisfied!

'Kill Bill: Volume 2' almost feels like an entirely different beast from Part 1. The pace is slowed down, action scenes are fewer and there is far more story unpacked in between to add some needed context and develop the character of "The Bride" a lot more. Where "Volume 1" is a dizzyingly stylish action-movie teaser, 'Volume 2' is more of a character-driven bulk of the "Kill Bill" story. Where Part 1 showcased "The Bride" as a badass of almost mythic prepositions, with some moments of needed vulnerability, while Part 2 reveals her as a fully-realized female character.  She is understandably more anger driven and brutal in Part 1 and Part 2 develops her character's motives coming from a place of love and disappointment. This added depth given to "The Bride" and a number of other character is by far 'Volume 2" most impressive attribute.


The cadence of this flick feels a lot more like a typical Tarantino movie, with long passages of deliberately paced scenes packed with pages of Tarantino's trademark dialogue and abrupt bursts of violence. It is never dull per say but I can say it is not as constantly entertaining as Part 1. Most of the scenes focused on Michael Madsen's Budd character drag a bit but maybe that was intended to illustrate how much of a loser this guy kind of is. There are plenty of terrific set-pieces scattered though-out and Tarantino's eye for violence remains quite captivating. The performances across both volumes are great. David Carradine is particularly mesmerizing as Bill. The man just oozes cool with his soothing voice and calm demeanor; you can believe this guy can be an unhinged asshole BUT he can help but enjoy whenever he is on-screen. 


Part 1 might have indulged in its stylish excess, it was still tightly structured with a runtime under two hours. Part 2 can be a bit over-indulgent in spots over two hours. There are a couple of scenes that could have trimmed down or cut out entirely; namely a scene with a creepy Spanish pimp named Esteban or Bill monologuing about a fascinating observation about Superman before reaching a point. But the movie sticks its landing in the end. I'm not sure how the four hour cut of the "Kill Bill" story would pan out with the two halves being tonally different from each other. However, not one can work without the other. Split the story into two certainly gives cinephiles a chance to appreciate two different ways of telling a story on the screen; It is literally combining style ("Volume 1") with substance ('Volume 2') and the Whole Bloody Affair of "Kill Bill" is an ambitious, imaginative fever-dream of Tarantino's pop culture influences and it is crazy how much it works. - 8/10 (B+)
Volume 2 is still a great film!
Pure entertainment. A lot more plot heavy than KB volume 1. Pretty grounded and awesome story told in Quentin fashion.
It lacked action and did not end the story well enough.
A Wonderful movie, I have to give it a 5 star review!

Kill Bill Volume 2 is awesome as well. It adds extra story, more incredible action scenes and it rises up the tension and the excitement. Something that I loved about this movie, that I think wasn't as clear in Volume 1, is how genious the script really is. The Black Mamba speech or the Superhero Comic Critic, are examples of the complexity of the script, I find it beautiful. And well, of course, this movie adds backstory and tells the ending of this great duo of films named Kill Bill, a must-see pair if you ask me.

Just like Volume 1, Kill Bill: Volume 2 is exciting, action-packed, and, like most Tarantino movies, just awesome in general. It dives deeper into the characters and story left vague from the previous film, and presents a satisfying conclusion that I don't think could have ended better.

This time feels more like a western, but this time isn't about just hitman's justice, but more about a mother looking for closure, but she finds more than that. I can only hope Tarentino makes more of this series.  "The Lioness has rejoined her cub and all is right in the jungle"
A really unique follow-up to the first volume with Uma Thurman still doing a bang-up job at taking names.
Not bad. The only thing that bugs me is how Kiddo did this seemingly did all of this for nothing, in the end, wiping her vigilante title away.
a great continuation of the story with the inclusion of backstory for the protagonist.
A good sequel. This is a completely different genre from the first and has a different feel/vibe. It's a bit slow but still has some action. Overall good movie. Vol. 1 is better.
I absolutely adore Kill Bill Volumes 1 & 2. I can watch these any time they come on television. Tarantino did a fantastic job here.

I actually didn't like Vol 2 as much as I liked Vol 1.

It's redeemed by the insanity of its plot and the epic cinematic styling it's comprised of, but mostly its faults are overridden by the quirky sensei man with the outrageous facial hair, if that man was inserted in some of the worst movies reviewed on this site, he just might possibly make many of them worth watching.
An epic storytelling at its best

Coming off the high of the first Vol. of Kill Bill, the second should have been no problem, since it's obviously the other half the film, right? Unfortunately, the genre blending and high octane energy of the first is mellowed out in a more sentimental yet, restrained second half that many boast as superior, when in reality it's just more-or-less a bit underwhelming. It may simply be the eye-candy of the first speaking, but the crux problem here is how more somber the tale becomes. What made the first a wild ride, was how far Tarantino blended genres together, weaving a narrative of films that have been lost in the rest of the world. Either the usage of actual anime to tell the backstory of O-Ren Ishii, to the mastery of knowing when to let the style go loose, only to recede back into the narrative, and among other things. While many state that Kill Bill Vol. 1 was the last great film from Tarantino, which is not true, I can understand if it was the last true time where genre blending was used so profoundly and masterfully. Because that, I agree, can be a debatable case. What made Kill Bill such a ride was the mixing of genres: Western, action, romance, etc. As a whole (both films) are unique idiosyncrasies, straight from the mind of Tarantino; meshing older films together to create something raw and yet controlled. The story itself is not terrible actually. The film bothers to give more depth to The Bride as her hunt continues to find and Kill Bill. Not only do we get to see how she became who she was, but we also see a stronger emphasis on Romance and connection between The Bride and Bill. I've stated that I believe this is the closest thing we'll get to a real romantic film from Tarantino. As both parts play seamlessly together to make this point. And what we get is the best romance out of any films he's made - except maybe Jackie Brown (1997). But the whole film feels rather pulpy, and too solemnly. Out of all Tarantino films he's made, this one is really discouraging for me to re-watch. I've seen the original film multiple times, each viewing easily improving upon the last. But this one is rather monotonous and tedious in pacing. Ironically having great scenes, the Superman speech alone is one of the best monologues ever written by Tarantino, and the tension in the final moments between the two lovers are effective, heartbreaking and yet satisfying. The film just drags out, unfortunately. No matter how good the action scenes are, it misses that wild spark of the original. Tarantino showed us how he mellowed down with his opus, Jackie Brown (1997) and Once Upon A Time In Hollywood (2019). Kill Bill was already an effective action/thriller, but the first also had a strong dramaturgy in it's core, which is why even when the film went overboard, it could be brought back down; it's that masterful technical and storytelling aspect that's so rare to see. While I do conclude Tarantino as one of the greatest working directors of our time, Kill Bill vol. 2 is certainly not the best example. It had some great aspects, but it's not enough for a bloated 2 hour and 30 minute runtime that could have been done shorter and with a sense of fun, passion and color.
A sublime spectactle that only does not stand out more because Tarantino has made more movies since then.
It's not quite as good as its predecessor, but Tarantino's vision is certainly executed, and the plane lands smoothly.

Think the 1st one is better, but this is a very good movie too.
There's less action and more slow situations, which I like very much.
Incredible movie!

Childhood love. No matter how good part 1 was, it was the second part that impressed me the most. The events in the film is a delight, sadness, regret. The soundtrack sounds like part of a whole. Complementing what is happening on the screen. The development of the main character, the way he goes through difficulties. What it comes to in the end. One of my favorite movies. Quentin, thank you for your love of movies.

This is one of those cases where the second movie beats the first.
Volume 2 is better. It gives us, if not fulfillment, completion of our objective.
The revenge story continues for the next volume of the best martial arts classic where the conclusion happens.

Just as awesome as the first, this movie continues The Bride's revenge adventure with gusto. Kill Bill volumes 1 & 2 will always be a set I recommend to anyone and everyone as an amazing time. Plus, Uma Thurman as The Bride is just amazing!
A bit darker that the first one but still interesting to learn more about the Bride's story and how it ends.
Not my favorite QT film, but it still has his comic flair, crazy and fun violence and strong characters.

People keep saying volume 2 is slower than the first but even though they're two separate movies they were meant to be watched together. The second movie is simply a continuation of the first. And there's still plenty of action in the 2 film to satisfy your needs. Honestly one of the best movies of all time. Quirky, funny, action packed, great dialogue- everything you'd expect from Tarantino. Must see action movie.
A conclusion that is successful this a great finale and watch these two back to back.

It's the dialogue heavy sibling to "Vol. 1", explaining and tying up all the loose ends with Tarantino's pretty punches of dazzling action and a refreshing climax. "Vol. 2" slightly etches out "Vol. 1" because I found its dialogue more magical than its radical style and it works better with having "Vol. 1"'s events kept as a mystery while it quickly recaps those events in its introduction. 
Honestly though, you shouldn't just see "Vol. 2" and call it quits. The two films are inseparable and play up each other's strengths to create a synergetic piece of adoring fiction.

I'm going to review these two volumes as one film, as they were intended. They complete each other in so many ways that I think it would be a completely unfair disservice not to, as I would give them both lower scores individually as they have flaws that the other volume makes up for in spades. This was originally intended as a 4 hour epic and BOY does it feel like one without ever slowing down pacing-wise like any movie half as long tends to feel trying to get the same approach. There's a very cheesy, self-indulgent, ultraviolent quality to volume 1 that's endearing and a wise, heartfelt finale with more restraint in the second that balance out perfectly. Together, you can't complain about the heartless violence when you want something more thoughtful or the lack thereof of the former in a revenge flick in the later because you've already had it. I personally prefer volume 2 over 1 because I enjoy the emotional attachment and the brains attached to what seemed like just a silly martial arts movie structured like a video game. It's all so well filmed and made that together make me want to rewatch the whole bloody affair just talking about it. But independently, yes, you could complain that volume 2 is anticlimactic as there's not much violence and that volume 1 is too violent too early, but together you get more than you asked for. Together, long stretches in volume 2 feel like small footnotes in a larger journey, the way they're intended to by the ten chapter structure. Together, this is a pretty complete film. Together, I give Kill Bill: Volumes 1 + 2 (I have not seen "the whole bloody affair") a 9.5/10!
Better that the first Kill Bill.  More story is added in this one and the characters feel more grounded in reality, than the previous installment.
The first one was a lot of fun and this one takes it up a notch and ends this great story. A must watch.
One of the best movies of the 2000s

An amazing ending to the first film.

Normally I'm skeptical of sequels but this one delivered on my expectations and then some. Tarantino's world-building and storytelling are showcased in this film as powerfully as the first film. The style of this film is distinct from the first one and provides a breathtaking view of the Kill Bill universe.

A great conclusion to the story.

4.5/5. Over-the-top, satisfying, and bloody brilliant.

Tarantino tones down the excessive blood squirting violence that defined 'Volume 1'. Make no mistake, this sequel is violent and graphic, but more thought out than just chopping up a hundred(ish) people in a room. Thurman is great again and Madson and Hannah are their nastiest best.
While I found the final battle a little weak, this was a great sequel and conclusion

I've been on a Quentin Tarantino kick. So I bought a 6 pack of digital codes for his older movies and have been watching his newer stuff on demand. I always have a hard time with the language, nudity, and gore in his movies, but the cinematography always carries me through and brings me back: Like most QT movies, this one is stuffed with vibrant wardrobe, well made real sets, perfect music and score, and excellent acting. If I was going to rank his movies, Kill Bill Vol 1 and 2 (which Quentin considers one movie, but the studio made him break it up into 2. For that reason, this movie has the same rating and review as Volume 1) would be right at the top of the list... Maybe 1st, maybe 2nd. But right at the top. I haven't watched the supercut released in 2011 called "the whole bloody affair", and I hope to rectify that soon. Needless to say, I highly recommend this movie to anyone interested in Tarantino, but also to audiences in general. It's excellently made and very engaging.

Kill Bill Vol. 2 may have lost half of the action and amazing details then the first one. However, I still enjoy the movie due to the performances of Uma Thurman and David Carradine, the screenplay and the finale. I do this movie credit for finishing the Kill Bill franchise, but I wish this movie shows more action that the first Kill Bill. Overall, Kill Bill Vol. 2 is a good take for Quentin Tarantino.
Not as great as volume 1 but still great. Would love a volume 3

Usually, the dialogue in Quentin Tarantino films are interesting and have meaning, but the dialogue in this one had little to no influence on this story and was very boring to listen to. The problem with this movie was that this was basically the whole movie. The action was cool and was just as good as the first film, but the writing for me lacked interest between the viewer and the story. So overall, this sequel was pretty disappointing for me. Every time the movie picked up pace it would immediately go back to boring, meaningless dialogue. Usually, I would be fine with this, but this went on for the whole movie, and that's why this movie was a bummer for me. This movie also spent about 5 minutes on how Budd is late for his shift at a bar that he works at. Dear movie, WE DON"T CARE THAT BUDD WAS LATE FOR HIS SHIFTS AT HIS STRIPPER BAR BOUNCER JOB SO WHY DID YOU SPEND SO MUCH TIME ON THAT.
Good movie but all in all I prefer the first

Suffering from a much weaker pacing and a whole lot of plot exposition, Kill Bill: Vol 2 is not nearly as effective, moving or investing as the first one but its performances keep it alive and the last 30 minutes delivers a well-rounded payoff.

It's like kill bill one but better and it didnt heve anime like the first one did so i enjoyed that a lot, if you loved the 1st then you'll probably love this one even more, but if you didn't then you probably still like this one more too but not by far also if you hate gore and blood (like me) then you'll love this one more
A damn good action thriller with great writing. And Uma Thurman kills it
A great continuation to a definitive action thriller of the early 2000s that has aged really well. A satisfying conclusion that can be viewed again many times and still be cool.

The things that worked the first time around are mostly back in terms of acting and action. However, there are major pacing problems. A disappointing final act also keeps this from reaching the heights of its predecessor.

Kill Bill: Vol 2 has much less action and its pace is a lot slower. However, for what it lacks in these places it makes up for in tension and emotion. The already great story is advanced by everything that happens in this movie. Beatrix's and Bill's characters are so well written. The story and themes are so mature and well drawn out. Much better film than Kill Bill: Volume 1. There's far more story, no excessive gore compared to Vol 1, and the cinematography and everything that Volume 1 got right remains just as good if not better. This film has a slower pace but that's a good thing and it certainly isn't boring for the most part despite what some idiots say on here.

The split between volume 1 and 2 feels organic, Kill Bill Volume 2 being vastly different in terms of style and tone. It's clear to see, the modern western style has influenced many films after, and I even think that something like the Fargo TV series borrows much of its non-Coen influences from this. 

Bill is finally introduced and he's a force of nature. A supreme being that elevates Tarantino's script to unfathomable levels. He's maybe the most perfect villain. 

The Chinese martial arts are a nice compliment to Volume 1's Japanese swordplay. The endless painful training blends well with the melancholic tone, every scene of the film fraught with regret and fear, the music all brilliant, wistful and deeply sad. The characters on Beatrix's list are all losers this time, flawed and miserable and damaged, perfect foils for her as her revenge story draws to a close. 

Pacing is slow but well constructed and allows for breathing room instead of the OCD and ADD of Volume 1. And that finale, the brilliant casting of B.B., the conversation in that perfect house, it's all lovely stuff, memorable and absolutely worth the wait.

Kill Bill Vol. 2

Tarantino's second and final volume of this gore-y tape is a profound quest for balance. I cannot emphasize more on how beautifully does this satisfying sequel carries the first one. If you were a bit squeamish in your first time, you will feel safe and more importantly enjoy this time- I'm talking about the film, The Film- with a neater narration in the driver's seat. Although I'd say that the writer and director Quentin Tarantino seemed a bit insecure about this volume. For he had kept all the cards hidden for this round. And hence, it could grow hefty for the viewers. But then you should never complain for too much substance.

For stylizing all the choreography on the other hand is Uma Thurman. By this half, she has sunken her teeth well enough to scare you. Her underrated performance knocks you down not by those one liners- never by them, in fact- or cool action tricks but sorrow and regret in her eyes, in her revenge when she claims it. That baffling response is surprising and human, tricking us into believing her. The film also covers the training of Thurman's character which focuses on balancing the emotions.

But I think it is the humble nature, the admiration that these so called "bad guys" have for the protagonist and the situation they find themselves in, is the actual nail in the coffin. Every kill, ever body that Thurman redeems tales something from her and us, and in order to portray that, Tarantino never rushes out the event. The calmness that these characters hold amidst the swooshing and whooshing of the cameras, never makes zero sense. The family in Kill Bill Vol. 2 that she returns to, that she is a part of, is familiar to us.

According to Uma Thurman, Tarantino had her watch three movies to prepare for this film: John Woo's "The Killer," Pam Grier in "Coffy," and Sergio Leone's "A Fistful of Dollars." If that sounds awesome to you, then the Kill Bill films are for you! Part two of what was originally planned as a 4-hour plus epic tale of revenge is even better than the first part. If Vol. 1 was primarily a homage to Asian genre cinema of the 60s and 70s, this installment is more a homage to westerns, particularly spaghetti westerns. Nods to others are certainly present (blaxploitation, rednecksploitation, muscle car movies, etc.), but this is primarily a western, which is wonderfully set up by Michael Madsen's down-on-his-luck international assassin character, Buck. Madsen's character could have simply been another sadistic Mr. Blond sociopath, but Buck has a tragic element to him. He was part of an elite group of international assassins, but he's now living in a trailer in the middle of the desert, working as a bouncer at a run down strip club, and even had to hock his Hattori Hanzo sword. Tarantino manages to give Buck a fair amount of character depth with minimal screen time, which is always a great thing to see. Though I think the action highlight of the film has to be the showdown between Uma Thurman and Daryl Hannah as the deadly one-eyed Elle Driver. Hannah had largely been absent from any films of note for quite some time, unless you count the Grumpy Old Men films ten years earlier and has sadly been absent from much since then, but she is terrific as Driver. I think a lot of credit also has to go to fight choreographer Yuen Woo Ping for the amazing fight between Thurman and Hannah in buds trailer. Tarantino also gets a lot of credit for selecting some truly badass Ennio Morricone music for their final moments. Tarantino includes in his cast some other cool character actors including Gordon Liu (as a white bearded kung-fu master this time), Sid Haig, and Larry Bishop. And then there is David Carradine as Bill, who finally show his face on screen this time, and who is excellent. I can't imagine anyone else playing this role, even though there were some very cool other actors under consideration to play Bill before Carradine was cast. As with most Tarantino films, this is not a film to suit all tastes, but for those who enjoy Tarantino's aesthetic, this film is a real treat.

As much as I enjoyed Volume 1 of Quentin Tarantino's 'Kill Bill' saga, I couldn't help but feel something was missing. The action, the style and the amazing soundtrack were all present, but the script was slightly lacking. In Volume 2, some much needed character development is finally realised, and the notorious Tarantino dialogue has returned. I felt much more invested this time round, in both the character of 'The Bride' as well as her endeavour. Bill is fleshed out, and the whole revenge plot finally takes on some deeper meaning, rather than just a bunch of cool fight scenes. Those fight scenes, by the way, are still absolutely there, but they feel more grounded; which I also appreciated. She doesn't take on a room full of people and emerge as the last woman standing like in Vol. 1. Instead, she appears much more vulnerable, and the fights are all one-on-one; making them far more engaging. I still have a problem with the way Tarantino has structured the story - in terms of how some parts are told out of order. It worked really well in some of his other movies like 'Pulp Fiction', but it doesn't quite have the desired impact here. Certain scenes, like Vol. 1, are also in black and white, and the reasons for this - whether it be stylistic or otherwise - were a poor choice because it does take you out of the movie. Luckily, in Vol. 2, it's far less prevalent. The performances are all great, and by the end Uma Thurman has really come into her own as this character. It was definitely a step above the previous instalment, and I would highly recommend seeking it out.

But this isn't as fast-paced nor entertaining as VOL 1 -- not even close. There're even some unclear motivations of some of the characters that they apparently forgot to clear out. Contrary to popular opinion I think Vol II of Kill Bill is the far superior chapter. We get Bill for starters and a fantastic buried alive scene. On reflection though I think that the whole Kill Bill thing would have been better as a single film.

The second chapter of this movie definitely suffers more from the choice to split it into 2 volumes. That is because, after all the insane action in the first movie, this one gets more of the smaller moments. There are a number of monologues, which are really excellent, but when you come into them from the more action-packed first half you're bound to be let down. It makes perfect sense that, after the over-the-top excess of the Crazy 88 scene, it was time to go smaller and more subdued. Tarantino definitely makes the right choices in Kill Bill Volume 2, it just would work better as the second half of a single film. Enough with being down on this movie, though, because I really liked it as well. The showdowns with Michael Madsen and Daryl Hannah were a treat (and got me to laugh out loud more than once,) and the flashbacks to her training made sense and also created a great reference point for other moments in this film. Perhaps the most surprising thing for me was the final showdown with Bill. It was one of those moments where I thought "how are they going to make this even remotely as strong as what came before?" Yet when I saw the conclusion I couldn't imagine it going any other way. Everything that was good about part 1 continued here in part 2, so I don't have much more to say. This is a great film, and the only thing that could have made it better would be if it were all one. In the future I'm sure I'll watch the 2 back-to-back and always treat it as one long film, so I think it will remain my favorite Tarantino film by far (although I could always be surprised by something new, you never know.)

The 2nd half of QT's revenge flick is certainly more weighty than its predecessor, managing to pack in almost an entire hour on top of the priors run time, but nothing can stop Kill Bill Vol 2 from suffering the same fate. If any QT movie was in need of Sally Menke giving it a rigorous chop, Death Proof aside, then this would and should have been the one. The double bill, always intended to be a single outing turned into a 2 part money making machine, suffers from being overly baggy, lacking substance and lacking any form of producer focus. Vol 2 see's Uma Thurman's, The Bride, now named Beatrix Kiddo, continue her bloody war path as she puts herself and everyone in her path, through hell, to get to her most prized target, Bill. Where Vol 1 at least had a frenetic energy to it, its completely clear that it also had all the punch, leaving Vol 2 to pick up all the pieces and cumbersome exposition. Vol 2 slogs along at a snails pace, taking a distinctly different approach than its sibling and ultimately leaving this double bill as more a mish mash of ideas rather than any coherent story. However with all its self indulgence, Vol 2 also offers up some brilliant cinematic moments that make it more riveting and iconic than your average 2 part film outing. A flash back to The Bride's training after she has been buried alive, is without a doubt the movies strongest moment, bolstering comedy, action and indeed a huge sense of anxiety for the protagonist. The much awaited confrontation between Ellie Driver and The Bride is also entertainingly brutal and expertly choreographed, giving the movie a much needed jolt towards the end. But Vol 2 just cannot shake its excess weight and sluggish pacing, and by the finale you will be fighting the urge to check your phone or indeed fall asleep. Kill Bill is ultimately a film maker in his prime, trying to cram as much inspiration into an outing as possible, on the whole some of it works brilliantly, our protagonist, the stylish visuals, the RZA's brilliant soundtrack, solid supporting actors and some intensely violent and harrowing moments and then of course there is the yawn inducing, self absorbed, drawn out dialogue, a structure so inconsistent you wonder if the film will even show up for the finale and indeed the overwhelming sense that this film is just not meant to be. Kill Bill Vol 2 will satisfy fans of QT on a very basic level, but as part of a bigger picture, its a wasted opportunity.

I recommend watching both volumes of Kill Bill back to back as one film. I believe the whole is better than the second part, which is a little too heavy with Tarantino's nerdy dialogue. The bloodshed continues in this conclusion to a great two-part film experience. It continues, but there is less of it as none of these villains rely on heavy arsenals of "bodyguards" as in the case of Cottonmouth in vol. 1.
The main thing this film accomplishes is that it fleshes out the main characters - The Bride and Bill - so much more than in the first installment. We actually get to see Bill's face throughout the film, witness the two having real conversations to develop their relationship, and we even witness some complex emotions from the Bride. Where the first Kill Bill was fun, vol. 2 is more about the characters.
This is not to say that vol. 2 is not a fun film. It is extremely fun - my friend audibly expressed satisfaction at certain moments throughout the film as it was his first time watching volumes 1 and 2 over the past two days. It is also notably very tense towards the conclusion of the film, and in this film Tarantino once again proves to be the master of the monologue with a great segment in which the mythology of a super hero is discussed. It certainly doesn't match up to the intro to Inglourious Basterds or Calvin Candie's monologue in Django Unchained, but its placement in the film is nearly perfect.
One disappointing factor of this movie is that, in my opinion, it seems to have a cop out instead of a well fleshed conclusion. I can't say much past this without a major spoiler, so I'll say you simply have to watch the movie to see what I am referring to. In a movie that incorporates the martial arts the conclusion may satisfy some, but I think it is a tad ridiculous compared to the rest of the two films put together.
While this film may impress me just a little less than the first, I am still eager to see The Whole Bloody Affair at a theater in my lifetime if I get the opportunity.

After re-watching Kill Bill: Vol. 1 of course I had to re-see Vol. 2 as well. At the end of Vol. 1 everything slowly came back to me. Why was this movie cut up in two parts again? How did I feel about it in 2004? How did I feel about it a decade later?

Like I said in my last review, Quentin Tarantino directed this movie and he wrote the story together with lead actress Uma Thurman. Thurman plays Beatrice Kiddo, also known as The Bride, who wakes up from a coma after four years to find that her unborn child is gone and that she was betrayed by a team of assassins that she used to be part of.

Both movies document the payback rampage she embarks on. While the first keeps the back story to a minimum, this second part delves deep into the history of Beatrice Kiddo. 

Problem is, from all the flashbacks and hints in the first movie, you already know what went on. Here, Tarantino is merely colouring a more elaborate picture of the set he's already outlined well enough for the story to hold.

So here I was with 130 of the 137 minutes still to go, thinking: "Oh yeah, I remember this. This is going to be long and drawn out and with a lot of bumps in the road."

And my memory served me well. Again, a decade later, I was wondering why this tale was cut up into two parts. So of course I looked it up. Thanks, Google. Seems like the story in 2003 was that the original movie was indeed intended to be 4 hours long and that the production company wanted to cut it in two parts because no audience would want to sit down that long. Or something close to that, depending on what source you visit.

This doesn't make sense to me. Granted, it's a plausible theory, something not many people would contend. But alas, I am a Cookie Monster, not people, and I am not satisfied with this explanation.

Vol.2 clearly was produced at the same time as Vol.1 with the same cast and production value. But the editing is quite different. Whereas Vol. 1 (111 minutes) flowed at a pleasant and regular pace, Vol 2 (137 minutes) seemed deliberately slowed down, while not really adding much to the back story that was absolutely necessary.

If I had enough time (which I don't, obviously, I barely have enough time to write all these reviews) I would load both installments into my Adobe Premiere and create my own edit to prove the following point: If you'd edit Vol. 2 the way Vol. 1 was done, removed all double scenes between the two installments and removed the double credit sequences, you'd end up with a running time under two and a half hours, which is perfectly fine for a single theatre release.

Anyway, I read some boo-hoos about how it was not easy for the production company to have to market this twice and have the second installment come out at a bad time for the Academy Awards, etc. Cowcrap, if you ask me. Just the news of the two installments was enough promo in itself, and why does no-one mention that all fans and viewers had to pay double the money to see the whole story?

This is still a great conclusion to the story, and provides with some great details to make Volume 1 even better.

I've never been much into the kind of movies that influenced Kill Bill. I was never much of a kung-fu guy, revenge flick guy and probably many of the references present were lost to me, but what separates a great filmmaker from an average one is that this movie niche should be enjoyed by everyone and those said references should never get in the way of a movie experience. Tarantino is a great filmmaker and Kill Bill is a blast from start to finish.

True, this might be the less inspired movie he's made so far when it comes to dialogues, instantly classic characters and it plods a little on the desert sequence but I'll be damned if I didn't enjoy every single bit of it. From the explosions of stylistic over the top gore, to the incredible cinematography, to the sheer brilliance of the pacing (giving us new things at every turn), Kill Bill is a difficult movie for those who won't be able to appreciate some of the camp and out of nowhere violent jolts, but all of this weird soup fortunately works together.

The only way to properly review this is to review it as it should be. As one film. After "Pulp Fiction'', director Quentin Tarantino spoke with Uma Thurman about doing a female led action film. Several years later, "Kill Bill'' was made. The film was split into two parts, both telling the same story. The film stars Uma Thurman, David Carradine, Lucy Liu, Michael Madsen, Daryl Hannah, Sonny Chiba, Vivica A. Fox, Gordon Liu, and Julie Dreyfus. If I had to explain the film in one sentence it would be: classic western meets Mexican mafia ninja warriors with an 80's vibe. Tarantino is known for making balls to the walls crazy films and Kill Bill could be his craziest. That being said, these films are not for everyone. I know plenty of people who hate them. If that's you, you can leave now, because these two films are some of the most impressive action movies I've ever seen.

The film follows Beatrix "Black Mamba" Kiddo (Thurman), a young women seeking revenge. On the day of her wedding rehearsal, Black Mamba is killed by Bill and her former team of fellow assassins. She lays in a coma for four years. When she wakes she realizes her baby has been lost and she vows to kill Bill for what he did. She goes on a killing rampage, killing off every member of her old assassin team until she makes it to the top. Until she makes it to Bill.

As a director, Tarantino is known for his crazy, bloody, and off beat films. Some people may not like his movies, but I love them. He does a phenomenal job with these films. This guy's first film was so good, it was like he was born a professional filmmaker. This movie is directed in such a artistic and energetic way. It shows how great this guy is. The script is also solid, showing true in the second volume. The second film has allot of smart dialogue that flows off the screen. The cinematography is done by Robert Richardson. He does a decent job filming the first volume, but the second was filmed even better. I loved the camera work in the second film. It was noticeably better and more precise. The performances in this movie are pretty good. Obviously, Uma Thurman steals the show, giving not only a solid performance, but kicking major a**. She really did a good job. I assume she had a stunt actor do allot of her stunts, but man where they good stunts.

Not only does this film have a good story, but it has amazing action. It's fast, stylish, and bloody. The fights are so well choreographed, and I have to give credit to the geniuses behind the stunts. Keith Adams and Woo-ping Yuen did phenomenal jobs with the stunts. Every stunt was uniq and exciting. The fight scenes were choreographed by Yuen Woo-ping, and they were so amazing. Every sword fight was intense, every knife fight was nail bitting. You can tell the man behind the fights knows what he's doing. 

Admittedly, the second volume isn't as exciting as the firs when it comes to action. It's a little slower as its predecessor, and lacks the engergy it had. However, it's not quite fair to say that seeing as I consider it to be one single film. The second one simply focus more on story than on action. That doesn't mean it's not a bit slow at times, but this is mostly forgivable. 

"Kill Bill'' is a film that may put off allot of people, but it will please die hard Tarantino fans for sure. I think it may be his best film next to "Pulp''. It's definitely one of the most impressive action films ever made. It's well directed, beautifully shot, well written, features great performances, has thrilling action, and tells a fantastically engaging story.

Somehow this Tarantino managed to out-due himself with the second movie. The story was very entertaining with many scenes that kept me on the edge of my seat. The ultimate revenge story concludes with  a bang! 5/5

Not as exciting or action-packed as Volume 1 (which I enjoyed a lot), but Kill Bill Volume 2 proves that Tarantino is a skilled, if not genius, writer and serves as a satisfying conclusion to this over the top Kung-Fu saga.

What a massive drop off from volume one of the movie. The reuse of Gordon Liu seems ridiculous and cheap for a movie of this pedigree. While Kill Bill: Volume 2 tries to infuse 80s 90s Hong Kong Kung Fu movie elements into the movie, it is unlike how it was done in the first one with all the Japanese elements. I'm not gonna tell you. This is a review, not a goddamn spoiler machine. God.
Anyway, Kill Bill: Volume 2 is the exciting conclusion to the Kill Bill saga, and it is quite awesome. I wouldn't say I enjoyed it as much as the first one, but it's still a bloody good movie that brings an awesome story to a satisfying end.
The movie picks up right where the first left off. The Bride is still hell bent of killing her former lover, while also trying to knock off the remaining members of her former team. It is a story loaded with great writing, action reminiscent of old Samurai movies (in all their bloody glory), scenes rife with tension, as well as a surprising amount of emotional parts. I never thought I would tear up at a Tarantino movie, but today I was proven wrong. I can't spoil the terrific scene that sparked so much emotion because it really catches you off guard, and it's a big contributor to the plot. Unlike the first movie, this one is a bit more complex in its plot, and it took a few unpredictable turns along the way, which is by no means a bad thing. The only complaint I have about the movie is that the beginning is pretty slow. The first one sucked you right in the second it started. This one takes a bit of time to get going, but once it does it's a damn fun ride.
Kill Bill: Volume 2 is a great movie. It's a great way to end an awesome saga that delivers in every category you'd expect a Tarantino movie to deliver in.

Among the Tarantino films I have watched multiple times, this is my least favourite.  Essentially, Tarantino does two things very well.  He distills what's most entertaining about genre cinema and takes the best parts and creates odd new mixtures out of the ingredients.  He writes riveting dialogue that lets him use long, dialogue driven scenes to drive his story.  He does the first in some amazing ways here ... blending ingredients from spaghetti westerns, martial arts films, horror films and other parts in new and dazzling ways.  He largely fails at the second task, or at least, fails often enough to make this film's long running time very very apparent.  There are a lot of scenes in this film don't engage, don't drive the story, and seem to exist mostly to insert actors Tarantino wants into the film (I'm looking at you Larry Bishop).  I have seen this film three times, and every time I see it, I realize I have idea what Uma Thurman and David Carradine talk about during the last 40 minutes.  That does not happen with any other of his films.

While the first part of Quentin Tarantino's epic revenge thriller was violent and very energetic, this second part is more about exposition of the story and characters. Naturally, Volume 2 is longer and more slowly paced than its predecessor. Besides, the characters are fleshed out very well, and I guess we owe that to all the exposition. The film shares its stylistic flair with its predecessor, and to great effect. As for the fight scenes, in this film, they seemed to go for an approach more reminiscent of old Western films, which also influenced the film's overall style. To say Kill Bill is one of Quentin Tarantino's best works is an understatement. Needless to say, it's one of the greatest movies I've ever had the pleasure to watch. After only intending to watch Vol. 1 during the night, I ended up binge-watching at 2:30 in the morning, in my pajamas, curled up at my TV screen with a hot mug of coffee in my left hand, and continued on towards Vol. 2. 

Vol. 1 was a flawless spectacle of perfected cinematography, intriguing dialogue, and of course, over-the-top violence (not to mention an unexpected Japanese Anime scene). Seamlessly woven together through Q.T's perfectionist screenwriting, we not only had our jaws open for four hours straight, but we all felt the raw, merciless anger radiated from Thurman's perfect portrayal of "feminine rage." 

Vol. 2 continued the tradition, and might I say, added so much more. For those that did not find Vol. 1 to meet their expectations, I'm sorry to say you won't find your spirits lifted in this one. Alas, for those that have been on the edge of their seats since the incredible cliffhanger Vol. 1 has left us with, I'm glad to say you will find yourself most entertained.

It's not often I give movies a perfect score, but a cinematic feat such as this rightfully deserves the recognition.

A very needed follow up to the first Kill Bill. It fills all of the unanswered questions of the first. Even though her acting was great in the first, Uma's performance is significantly better in this one. As a stand alone film, it is all story with very little and shortened action.

By choosing to tell the story in two parts, Quentin Tarantino was able to fully flesh out the Kill Bill saga in all aspects. With part 1, he gave us style. With part 2, he has given us substance. The characters are given weight, and their actions are given meaning, retroactively creating a 2-volume masterpiece.

Where Kill Bill: Volume 1 was a brash, fun, uber-violent, pop-culture ladened play session for Quentin Tarantino, Volume 2 aims to slow things down a bit, and provide some much-needed depth to this tale of revenge. Gone is the huge body count, and in its place, we're treated to a great story of betrayal and violence within the ranks of globe-trotting assassins for hire.

In the second installment, we learn why The Bride (Uma Thurman) tried to escape from Bill (David Carradine), and why Bill hunted her down. As we travel with The Bride on her adventures we get to learn more about her relationship with Bill, and where she received her martial arts training. The Bride is still on her quest for vengeance, but this time around instead of long drawn out flashy fight sequences, the action in volume 2 comes in short loud bangs.

This is not to say I liked one volume over the other because to be honest they are different kinds of films, and they both can be enjoyed for what they are. If anything, the slower pace of the second installment is a welcome break from all the mayhem, and actually feels more mature. The pop-culture references are toned down, and the film aims to pack a bigger emotional punch through Quentin Tarantino's superb dialog.

As with the first installment, Uma Thurman's performance shines, and it was nice to see David Carradine in front of the camera in the second film. This movie also gives Michael Madsen and Daryl Hannah some very welcome screen time.

Movie Prep:

If you're expecting more of the same with volume 2 you will be disappointed. The body count is a lot lower in the second film, and there are less martial arts sequences. This film is slower than the first, but provides more depth. Less cool, yet more mature.

Best Format:

Kill Bill: Volume 2 is reasonably well shot so a HD viewing at home is recommended.

So this is part two of two of my Kill Bill review.

Personally, I have wavered in my rating of Volume 2 from a 4 or a 4.5, and possibly even a 5. Whether intentional or not, there is noticeable difference between Volumes 1 and 2 in pacing and style. Unlike the first part, this movie really transcends traditional genre lines and injects more dialogue and saccharinity  into the story of the Bride.

Ultimately, what makes me so appreciative of this second half to the story is that it is able to complement the first so well. All the Deadly Vipers are now accounted for, and not all in the ways we expected. We see David Carradine's face and then see his take on things. And finally we see the legendary Five Point Finger Exploding Heart Technique. With all the madness and bloodshed, it all ends and things are done right by the Bride.
While anticlimactic compared to the Crazy 88 showdown of Vol 1, Kill Bill Volume 2 is still another win for Tarantino. It should be noted that this was originally the latter end of Vol 1.

Though this film is not as tight as the first, and allows itself to meander a bit too long through martial arts genre tropes, Kill Bill Vol 2 is an emotionally satisfying end to the Brid/ incredible saga. It's talky, sure, but hearing Quentin Tarantino talk through his characters is more entertaining than most movies' climactic action scenes.

Sometimes a sequel is completely different from the first and still manages to impress me. Unfortunately, "Volume 2" is not one of those times. It upsets me to say it, as I loved the first entry of this series, but this one was so mediocre. It is nothing like the first in almost every way. I liked that it was character focused and we got to see some more backstory, but the movie just felt like a snooze to me. I enjoyed a few fight sequences in this movie but it certainly has nothing as memorable as the fights in "Volume 1." Uma Thurman is good again and her character is still certainly likable, but it's not enough to save the movie. While the first movie stands as one of my favorite films from Quentin Tarantino, this one easily stands as one of my least favorites from him.

I honestly think that if you combine volume 1 & 2, and view it as one big movie, Kill Bill can be way better. In my opinion, this isn't a series of  2 movies. It's one big epic that was split apart for whatever reason by production, and it really brings this story down. For full effect, next time I revisit Kill Bill, I'm gonna try and give it all a go in one sitting, instead of seeing them as two different movies. They're really not.

In volume 2, The Bride's journey is slowed down, when her foes become much more aware of her rampage, challenging her in many different ways. Along the way, the whole narrative slows down to tell more stories of origins, and background to the whole story. The Bride is slowly crossing off the names on her kill list, to the point where she is finally face to face with Bill, her final boss.

Volume 2 is a completely different experience from Volume 1. Volume 1 hits you hard, and spits blood from the screen as the bodies just pile up. It's high octane combat, with a bit of story in the background. It's exciting, but Volume 2 doesn't bring more of that. Volume 2 stops right in it's tracks and gives you more story, more origins, and more character development through the use of Tarantino's slick dialogue. It's still quite funny and campy, but a lot more dramatic. It's a bit longer, but that's welcome with a revenge story this interesting.

However, this one moves much slower than the first part. I hate comparing sequels to predecessors, and parts of series to each other, but sometimes it's inevitable. The pacing changes completely here, and while there are still some great action scenes, Volume 2 does a good job on focusing on the importance of the bride's revenge. We see more from her perspective, creating a more intense hunger for her well deserved revenge. It's well done, but I can't help but feel some of the stuff in Volume 2 features some of the poorer writing on Tarantino's behalf. Even though this is the case, Tarantino's average writing is still better than half of hollywood. Kill Bill as a whole can be seen as a revenge epic that works as a great tribute to spaghetti westerns and samurai films, but is more importantly a great big reminder from Tarantino on what it means to go to the  movies and be entertained.

Kill Bill Vol. 2 gets slower and more serious, but features enough sharp dialogue and story development to provide a solid conclusion to the revenge epic.

Fox (Independence Day), Lucy Liu (Charlie's Angels), Michael Madsen (Reservoir Dogs), Daryl Hannah (Blade Runner), Uma Thurman (Pulp Fiction) as the Bride and David Carradine (Kunf Fu) as Bill. With guest appearances of Samuel L. Jackson (Pulp Fiction) and Sid Haig (Coffy). She's back for the final cut! 

With O-ren Ishii (Liu) and Vernita Green (Fox) dead, the Bride (Thurman) continues her vengeance quest to kill her former boss Bill (Carradine), his brother Budd (Madsen) and the one-eyed Elle Driver (Hannah), who were all responsible for the Wedding Massacre at the Two Pines four years earlier. The next on her death list is Budd, who works as a bouncer in a strip club and lives his lonely life in a trailer. But he expects her and is able to capture the woman, putting her in a coffin and burying her alive. Claustrophobic and tied up, the Bride remembers the training Bill made her follow from martial arts master Pai Mei. Can she escape and get her bloody satisfaction?

Verdict: 4.7 Stars/ 5 Stars
Kill Bill Vol. 2 proved to be not your ordinary revenge flick, and justified the and made the first one much more improved. It may lack exhilarating action that most audience expect, but what it offers is much more than that- a thought, a dilemma a very complicated story and an absorbing emotion driven ride. Complete doses of everything from action, dialogue, acting, character development, humor and sense of style. Kill Bill Vol. 2 is so out of the box and is definitely not an average revenge flick.

Totally makes good on the mysterious hints of real character and narrative dropped in Vol. 1. The third act achieves the overwhelming poignancy of a master tragedy. It totally subverts the otherwise bland expectations the murder laundry-list format sets up for itself.
Despite it has been toned down. Kill Bill vol. 2 excel in its screenplay and Tarantino's art of storytelling and cinematography.
Part 2 of this revenge story. Less action, not as stylish, and more exposition and drama.
From old style martial arts to western style is a hard transition to pull off but kill bill vol 2 pulls it off and is still as entertaining as its predesscor.

"Kill Bill, Volume 2" picks up, right where "Kill Bill, Volume 1" left off: full of brutal violence and thrill.  However, as Q.T. tends to do, he adds a twist.  Quentin, introduces us to Black Mamba's daughter and for a second you think things might change.  In the end, however, he does the right thing and gives us all the ending we've been waiting for.
Kill Bill Vol. 2 is stunning. It has flashbacks, great action sequences, and is a great conclusion to the two-parter.

Kill Bill volume 1 was an outstanding movie, the best way I could describe it is a spaghetti western with samurai swords and one pissed off bride. Kill Bill volume 2 is a great film that almost lives up to the original. In a way Kill Bill volume 2 is very different to the first one as it has very little action and is more about the dialogue. However Kill Bill volume 2 is still a great film. It's a very good way to rap up all the loose ends. Has some amazing scenes, the bride being buried alive is the first one that comes to mind. Uma Thurman is excellent as are the other actors. I think it all wraps up very well. However one problem and its a very common one about this movie is the climax between Bill and the Bride. Now we do get some excellent dialogue in this film, but after the whole crazy 88 fight scene at the end of the last movie you kind of hope that the fight between Bill and the Bride would be better but it's extremely short. Flaws aside this is a great movie that I absolutely love. A
not bad, not as exciting as the first, but great storytelling.  anti climactic ending though.
It had that Tarantino vibe, but it fell short for me.  Ontop of that I don't like paying to see half of a movie.
as good as the first one. no room for disapointment! Tarantino ended his story perfectly! Chapeau!

Kill Bill Volume 2 is the continuation of The Bride's story in getting her revenge against Bill. I consider Kill Bill as one of Tarantino's weaker films, and Volume 2 is definitely a big reason why it's a letdown.

The film is written by Quentin Tarantino and what he has written here is much more dialogue and story heavy than the first volume. I enjoyed the first volume a lot more because it is much more fun and stylish, this second volume holds back much more of that in service to the story which wasn't all that great to begin with. Normally heading towards the end, a film with this story should be much more intense than the first half but that's not the case. The bulk of the build up of the climax is dull due to the underwhelming dialogue, though the pregnancy test sequence was hilarious. The climax itself would have been a great opportunity for Tarantino to write something spectacular and thrilling, yet it felt like Tarantino couldn't find some sort of vision of it and just wrote something that can be done swiftly. I know Tarantino can write because he has proven it with great dialogue-driven films like Pulp Fiction and Death Proof or mainstream action driven films like Inglourious Basterds and Django Unchained. Kill Bill combines both aspects together and proved to be ineffective. The film's story isn't all bad with an interesting burial segment and a throwback to the old Kung-Fu Chinese films that had me smiling throughout.

Tarantino directs this film with a much more slower pace, in order to flesh out the story and gain more insight to it's characters. This film at times feels too safe for me, with moments that have characters just talking, which I don't mind if the dialogue was written better, leaving me feeling underwhelmed. Kill Bill as a whole's best moments are the segments that are over the top, violent and experimental. These experimental moments include the Pai Mei chapter, feeling like it was from a 1980's cheesy Kung Fu film. If Tarantino treated this half of the film like the first half then Kill Bill as a whole would have been an instant favorite of mine.

Robert Richardson comes back as the director of photography for this film and this time the scenes don't look as hyper stylised and overly saturated as the first volume. I do admire the fact that this film doesn't look the same the entire run of the film, with moments in black and white, changing the aspect ratio of the film, and using split screen to show two things at once. The Pai Mei sequence was shot in such a way that is similar to the old Asian Kung Fu films, with grainy photography and lacking in vibrancy in it's color. Though there are great moments in this volume's photography, I much prefer the style that was applied for the first volume.

RZA didn't come back to do the score for this film, which is odd as I liked what he did for the first volume. Instead Robert Rodriguez is credited for the music of the film, I am sure that he did the final song but I am not aware of any other moments in where he might have contributed. The film's music still follows that inspiration of Ennio Morricone, with some tracks actually written from him, and gives the film this Western feel to it. There are also moments where it uses Asian inspired music which works well with the tone of the film. The sound effects of this film is hilarious as they use the cheesy effects that are found on the films that this was inspired by. I wish that this film does retain that upbeat and fun soundtrack that fueled the first volume, but I guess that would be inappropriate judging by the events that unfolds during this film.

Uma Thurman as The Bride is still great but this time it seems the film demands more from her and she does a great job. She may seem less bad-ass here because vulnerabilities arise and there are times where she is outmatched by her opponent which we didn't see a lot from the first volume. I felt that Bill was a little dull because of the way Tarantino has written him, but David Carradine does the most he can with the character. Daryl Hannah and Michael Madsen as Elle and Budd were fun to watch as they play characters that are classic Tarantino; fun, hilarious, and unpredictable. I wish Madsen were in much more entertaining films because he is a wonderful actor to watch. Gordon Liu as Pai Mei was definitely hilarious and written with such absurdity that anything that comes out his mouth is pure comedic gold or bad-ass.

Kill Bill Volume 2 is a bit of a disappointment in comparison to the first volume and the other films in the director's catalogue. If the film was fun like the first one, or at least written better then I would have liked this film a lot.

Kill Bill Volume 2 was ... a lot more fun than Volume 1. I suppose the scenes where i laughed are really meant to be laughed at. There was a little surprise which really slapped me up in the end, and it was a damn good slap. A must watch sequel!

Maybe even better than V.1...!

Very disappointing. I'm a big fan of Tarantino's preference to dialogue and meaning over mindless action. Lengthy, wordy, intellectual conversations are really what make his films more than just well executed action, but intelligent stories with compelling characters as well. Kill Bill Vol. 1 was just an action flick, I accept that. Kill Vill Vol. 2, however, treads this nasty water in between the mindless action and the wordy dialogue. The conversations may be slow in this film, and they may take away from the fast pace, but I would not find fault with that, were the conversations actually interesting or compelling in any way. Apart from Bill's brief spiel about Superman, there is not a word of compelling or interesting conversation in the movie. The story of The Bride is, frankly, not all that interesting or intelligent. Conversations about it are not either. Tarantino's really misstepped with his own formula this time, and that's unfortunate. At least his next two films are some of the greatest ever made. He clearly learned how to make great movies again.
Not as good as the first part, but still, lots of blood and action in this sequel makes this film another QT's classic.

This series was better than I expected it to be honestly. Just really good action movie with that Tarantino twist..... This one had a lot less gore in it, which made me appreciate the story more. I may have to check out some other Tarantino titles. It's been years since I've seen Pulp Fiction......
